questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: A systematic way to do projects in R and save it.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: At the end of this course, I hope I will be able to confidently create and make use of functions. Basically, just get a better workflow and grasp of R and how it can be used optimally for data cleaning and management

questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: Be better at functions and work in Markdown with Git

questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: Become more proefficient in writing code in R, especially using loops and functions

questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: Better understand of R, Rstudio and Git and learning to use it more systematically in data analysis and management

questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: Functions baby! I just hope to expand my R knowledge and learn new ways to optimize my coding while keeping it reproducible.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: Hopefully I will be more confident in using different tools to ensure proper reproducibility in my research

questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?

questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I am expected to learn a better way to write reproducible codes, make and use efficient functions

questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I expect to get greater knowledge on R language and reproducible data to use for my own reproducible analyses. I got a good insight and understanding of R and Git/GitHub connection at the intro course and therefore anticipate to get even more knowledge and understanding from the intermediate course. I am to start my own analyses soon and hopefully I can apply this knowledge when working with my data.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I expect to learn how I can work with datasets; download, cleaning up and processing. And how this is done in a reproducible and open way.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I expect to learn the tools of how to start analysing my data in R (which I will do over the summer). As I will be collaborating with others, it will be great to expand my knowledge in reproducibility, data tidying and sharing via Git.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I hope to gain basic skills in reproducible data management and data analysis for my research year project.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I hope to learn to write more clear scripts, that are easier to get back to and understand

questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I learnt a lot from the introduction course, and I hope to be able to add on to the skills learned there. I am currently working with data analysis, and I hope to learn how to optimize my work.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I would just like to continue on my R and reproducibility journey as I thought the first course was absolutely excellent, and I've been able to use a lot of the tools I learned from that course in my research. I don't think I have a specific goal in mind for what I'd like to learn.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I would like be more comfortable writing code in R and rely less on copy pasting old code that I know works.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I would like to learn and pratice cleaning up my data. Using tidyverse. I often struggle with analyzing my results, what does my results show, and what can i conclude.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: Learn how to use functionals and not repeat my self a 1000 times in one script, learn better R-workflow and more efficient coding and learn why GitHub is so nice

questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?

questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: To be able to use more functions in R, besides basic R. To more effectively run codes. To be more structured. To save time on data management and analysis.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: To be better at processing and cleaning data in R studio. To improve my R coding in general.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: To improve my skills in reproducible research in R, which I started learning in the beginner level course. I would like to conduct my analyses in a reproducible way.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: All of it, it was easy to follow and gave source for further reading if interested.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: As I already participated in the introduction course, I used what I had learned to make minor alterations to the code in the setup of the project. This is to separate the introduction and intermediate course, and also practice what I have worked with before. This explains my project setup, as I called the project IntermediateR3 instead of LearnR3. With the intro-knowledge I could already follow the structure of setting up the project and connection to Git/GitHub.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Everything worked well for me

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Great that you had an pre-course were you actually had to hand in a task or product. Great idea in order to 'start on the same page' so to speak.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: I like how the pre-course tasks material is structured.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: I like that it is structured, and the "how to read the code" is very helpful to understand what exactly are we commanding

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: I really think it works well the overall structure, as we get an introduction to the code, then the actual code and the expected output

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: I think it all worked well, I'm especially fond of the fact that there's really nothing left to confusion, as is so often the case in other courses where you're left to figure out for yourself.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: I wasn't able to install the necessary package. May be a problem on my end. Will try to troubleshoot before the course

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: In general the structure and information regarding the precourse assignments.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Installing R

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: It was a really nice tutorial. It all worked and I learned something along the tutorial.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: It was well structured and informative

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: It worked really well. I got a little lost in the Git setup and did way to many tasks compared to what was asked, but that might be me not reading the directions properly.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Nice to be sure all is installed and downloaded before. Nice information load.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: No complaints, easy to read and follow along.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Task where you have to do the tings you just read about. I like that you show examples of everything - in this way you are sure that you did it right.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: The codes

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: The descriptions are nice and thorough, ensuring that everyone can follow along, regardless of their level of skill going in

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: The detailed descriptions.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: The guided code

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: The material is very detailed and prepares you for the course as well as you find out what you need to read up on before hand

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: The step-by-step and elaborate description for each pre-course tasks (including "it should now look like this, et cetera) is great for a "beginner" like me to ensure everything is right :)

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: The survey is a good way to make sure that we did it

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: The tasks are super fine. It was for me very confusing that the preparation/website for the beginner course was visually such a like. I havent done that course and had to jump back and forth between the two sites during preparation but I find I hard to figure out which one of them I was during (hope it make sense)

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: The website guide is super well thought out and easy to navigate in. Good w the pre-course tasks so setup does not take time out of the course (+ the tasks gives you an idea of the course/programs you will use)

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Very clear and nice to be able to read up on everything.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Very detailed and understandable description of the task

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Very nice to be able to copy the code directly.. it would have taken huge amounts of time to write the code myself at the stage I am at right now and that would just be frustrating and demoralizing. I loved the step-wise guide to what was needed to be done and where the ressources were.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: good to make sure that everyone is on the same level. have the right installations. nice that it wasn't hardcore statistic tasks

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: A little bit hard to get an overview in the sections. But then again I did not take the beginner course and therefore were a little behind in the way of doing things.

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: All in one document so you do not have to jump from one to another and back again

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: As I have the LearnR3 project on my desktop from the first course, I couldn't just follow the pre-course tasks to setup the project folder. Maybe you could add, that if one had already participated in the introduction, they could either open that project and then download data for intermediate, or they should rename the project directory to something else.

questions: Please describe the problems you've had.
responses: Couldn't download the mmash dataset from the physio-website (I tried several times). Download was too slow, so it timed out after 60 secs. The alternative link provided for when physio website was slow did not work for me

questions: Please describe the problems you've had.
responses: I could not install r3

questions: Please describe the problems you've had.
responses: I got error with the following: pak::pak("rostools/r3"); r3::install_packages_intermediate(); r3::create_qmd_doc()

questions: Please describe the problems you've had.
responses: I had to restart R to make the r3::check_setup() to work

questions: Please describe the problems you've had.
responses: I know my r3::check_project_setup() doesn't look exactly as it should because even though I deleted the files I was meant to, somehow they were put into another folder named "multilevel-monitoring-of-activity-and-sleep-in-healthy-people-1.0.0". At that point though I didn't have time to do the whole thing again, and figured that at least all the files were contained in one spot and I could perhaps easily delete that later.

questions: Please describe the problems you've had.
responses: When running "pak::pak("rostools/r3") it mostly seems to work until I get an error: ! error in pak subprocessCaused by error in `process_initialize(self, private, command, args, stdin, stdout, â€¦`:! Native call to `processx_exec` failedType .Last.error to see the more details.
